case_id: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Naresh (2011) 4 SCC 324
facts: Incident occurred on the evening of 07.07.1994 in Village Nagla Singh, P.S. Kotwali Dehat, District Etah, Uttar Pradesh.
An altercation took place between Naresh (Accused-Respondent) and Ram Kishan (Deceased) near a 'kharanja' (brick-paved path).
During the altercation, Naresh allegedly hit Ram Kishan on the head with a 'brickbat' (roa).
Ram Kishan fell down after being hit.
Ram Kishan was taken home by eyewitnesses.
Ram Kishan succumbed to his injuries the next morning, 08.07.1994.
FIR was lodged by Ram Bharose (PW1, relative of deceased) on 08.07.1994 at 7:15 AM.

Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. R.B. Singh (PW5) revealed one lacerated wound on the right side of the head (6 cm x 2 cm x bone deep) and internal injuries including a fracture of the right temporal bone and subdural haematoma.
Cause of death was determined as coma resulting from the ante-mortem head injury.
Key eyewitnesses included PW1 (Ram Bharose), PW2 (Nathu Singh), and PW4 (Babu Ram), who testified seeing Naresh strike the deceased.
PW3 (Smt. Kamlesh), wife of the deceased, testified about the altercation and seeing her husband injured.
The Investigating Officer (IO), SI Ram Veer Singh (PW7), prepared the site plan, collected blood-stained earth, and arrested the accused.
The Trial Court convicted Naresh under Section 304 Part II, IPC and sentenced him to 5 years Rigorous Imprisonment.
The State of Uttar Pradesh appealed to the Allahabad High Court.
The High Court allowed the appeal, altering the conviction from Section 304 Part II to Section 302 IPC and sentencing Naresh to life imprisonment.
Naresh (represented by the State as he absconded during appeal, but judgment impacts him) appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 304 Part I (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - with intention of causing death or bodily injury likely to cause death)
Section 304 Part II (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - with knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, but without intention to cause death/such bodily injury)
Section 300 (Murder definition, including Exceptions, particularly Exception 4 - Sudden Fight)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The act of hitting the deceased on the head with a brickbat constitutes Murder under Section 300 Clause Thirdly, as the accused intended to cause a bodily injury sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.
precedents: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)
State of A.P. v. Rayavarapu Punnayya (1976) 4 SCC 382)
Rajwant Singh v. State of Kerala (AIR 1966 SC 1874)
elements: Accused caused bodily injury to the deceased.
The specific injury intended was inflicted.
The injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of clear evidence proving specific intention to inflict *that particular injury* which was sufficient to cause death. Use of a common object (brickbat) and a single blow suggest intention might only be to cause hurt or grievous hurt, not necessarily a fatal injury.
supporting_precedents: Jagrup Singh v. State of Haryana (1981) 3 SCC 616)
Pappu v. State of M.P. ((2006) 7 SCC 391)
Mer Dhana Sida v. State of Gujarat ((1985) 1 SCC 200)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The eyewitness accounts (PW1, PW2, PW4) are consistent and reliable regarding the assault by Naresh, establishing his culpability beyond reasonable doubt.
precedents: State of U.P. v. Anil Singh (AIR 1988 SC 1998)
Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1988 SC 696)
Leela Ram v. State of Haryana ((1999) 9 SCC 525)
elements: Presence of witnesses at the scene.
Corroboration regarding the weapon (brickbat) and act (striking the head).

counter_arguments.loophole: Minor discrepancies in witness testimonies regarding lighting conditions or exact location; delay in lodging FIR (incident evening, FIR next morning); PW1 being related to the deceased might suggest potential bias or tutoring.
supporting_precedents: Thulia Kali v. State of T.N. ((1972) 3 SCC 393)
Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra ((1978) 4 SCC 371)
Marudanal Augusti v. State of Kerala ((1980) 4 SCC 425)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Exception 4 to Section 300 (Sudden Fight) is not applicable as the accused took undue advantage by using a weapon (brickbat) against an unarmed person and acted cruelly by hitting a vital part (head).
precedents: Narayanan Nair R. v. State of Travancore-Cochin (AIR 1956 SC 99)
Kirpal Singh v. State of U.P. (AIR 1965 SC 712)
State of M.P. v. Saleem ((2005) 5 SCC 554)
elements: Proof of undue advantage taken by accused.
Proof of cruel or unusual manner of acting by accused.

counter_arguments.loophole: A 'brickbat' is not a sophisticated weapon but an object likely found at the scene; a single blow may not necessarily constitute 'cruel' action or 'undue advantage' in the context of a sudden altercation.
supporting_precedents: Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana ((2002) 3 SCC 327)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. ((2003) 3 SCC 528)
Surain Singh v. State of Punjab ((1976) 4 SCC 254)

defense_arguments.argument: The act falls under Exception 4 to Section 300 (Sudden Fight), reducing the offence from Murder to Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder.
edge_cases: Determining if picking up a readily available object constitutes 'taking undue advantage'.
Assessing if a single blow constitutes acting in a 'cruel or unusual manner'.
precedents: Surain Singh v. State of Punjab ((1976) 4 SCC 254)
Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana ((2002) 3 SCC 327)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. ((2003) 3 SCC 528)

defense_arguments.argument: There was no intention to cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death (mens rea for Sec 302/304 Part I absent). The act was done with knowledge that it might cause harm or, at most, knowledge it was likely to cause death (Sec 304 Part II).
edge_cases: Inferring intention solely from the nature of the injury and weapon.
Distinguishing between intention to cause a specific fatal injury (Sec 300 Thirdly) and intention to cause injury that happens to be fatal.
Single blow vs. repeated blows as indicator of intent.
precedents: Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148)
Jagrup Singh v. State of Haryana ((1981) 3 SCC 616)
Rampal Singh v. State of U.P. ((2012) 8 SCC 289)

defense_arguments.argument: Inconsistencies in eyewitness accounts and delay in FIR cast reasonable doubt on the prosecution's version.
edge_cases: Impact of minor vs. major discrepancies.
Plausibility of explanation for FIR delay.
Reliability of related witnesses without independent corroboration.
precedents: Kali Ram v. State of H.P. ((1973) 2 SCC 808)
Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra ((1984) 4 SCC 116)
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. High Court judgment set aside. Trial Court judgment convicting Naresh under Section 304 Part II IPC restored.
reasoning: The incident occurred due to a sudden quarrel without premeditation.
The weapon used was a 'brickbat' (roa), not a deadly weapon carried beforehand, but picked up during the altercation.
Only a single blow was inflicted on the deceased.
The accused did not take undue advantage or act in a cruel or unusual manner; hitting with a readily available object in a sudden fight doesn't automatically constitute undue advantage.
The case falls under Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC (Sudden Fight).

While the injury was on a vital part (head) and proved fatal, the circumstances (sudden quarrel, single blow, common object) indicate lack of intention to cause death or that specific injury sufficient to cause death (required for Sec 300 Thirdly).
The accused must be attributed with knowledge that such an injury was likely to cause death.
Therefore, the conviction should be for Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder under Section 304 Part II IPC.
